testMsg:
Answer 20 questions including 5 value questions in 45 mins.

Score 75% or more to pass the test.
earnMsg: Watch sponsored content to earn 3 credits?

questions.questionText: What are some examples of undermining Australia’s interests and damaging community relations?
options: Promoting distrust in and fear of an ethnic community
questions.explanation: For example, using social media to share official government secrets would be undermining Australia’s interests. Similarly, promoting distrust in and fear of an ethnic community would damage Australian community relations.

questions.questionText: How many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages are included in Australian culture?
questions.explanation: In Australia, other languages are also valued, including more than 100 distinct Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander languages.

questions.questionText: What are the laws regarding divorce in Australia?
options: There are no laws regarding divorce in Australia
questions.explanation: Divorce is acceptable in Australia..

questions.questionText: What should people who serve in the Australian parliament feel?
questions.explanation: It is an honour and a serious responsibility to serve in an Australian parliament

questions.questionText: When was the bushfire season in Australia?
questions.explanation: During Australia’s devastating bushfire season of 2019-20, which resulted in the loss of life, property and wildlife, and environmental destruction, many multicultural communities worked to collect money, clothes and food donations to help people affected by the bushfires.

questions.questionText: Who can serve in a jury if called upon?
Which flag is the official flag of Australia?
questions.explanation: The Australian National Flag is the official flag of our nation

questions.questionText: What does the shield in the centre of the Commonwealth Coat of Arms represent?
questions.explanation: The shield in the centre represents the six states and federation

questions.questionText: What sort of behaviour comes under domestic or family violence?
options: A: Threats to control a partner
B: Causing fear or threatening the safety of your partner
questions.explanation: Domestic and family violence includes behaviour or threats that aim to control a partner by causing fear or threatening their safety

questions.questionText: Can any Australian citizen who is aged 18 years and over seek election to parliament at the federal, state and territory level?
options: Australian citizens can’t seek election to parliament
questions.explanation: Australian citizens who are aged 18 years or over, and who are not dual citizens, can seek election to parliament at the federal, state or territory level

questions.questionText: What are some of the icons of Western Australia?
questions.explanation: Western Australia’ s icons include the Ningaloo Coast, Margaret River, and the Kimberley region

questions.questionText: What is South Australia famous for?
questions.explanation: South Australia has a rugged coastline and many famous wine regions

questions.questionText: What does a jury do?
options: They listen to evidence in a court case
They make sure that everyone gets a chance to trial
They are just there to listen to what the judge says
questions.explanation: A jury is a group of ordinary Australian men and women who listen to the evidence in a court case and decide if a person is guilty or not guilty

questions.questionText: How can Australian citizens make sure their children born overseas are also Australian citizens?
options: A: By applying for their children to become an Australian citizen by descent
B: By applying for their children to become an Australian citizen through taking a test on their behalf
questions.explanation: Australian citizens can apply for their child born overseas to become an Australian citizen by descent.

questions.questionText: What are government ministers responsible for?
options: Only the areas allotted to them by the Prime Minister
questions.explanation: Government ministers are responsible for an area of government(called a portfolio), such as employment, Indigenous Affairs or the Treasury

questions.questionText: Does sexual orientation have anything to do with the type of treatment you get from others?
options: Depends in which area you live
You need to hide your sexual orientation
questions.explanation: Australians are expected to treat each other with dignity and respect, regardless of their race, country of origin, gender, sexual orientation, marital statu, age, disability, heritage, culture, politics, wealth or religion.

questions.questionText: Where do the Torres Strait Islands lie?
questions.explanation: The Torres Strait Islands lie to the north of the Queensland state and the world - famous Great Barrier Reef runs along its eastern coast

questions.questionText: Which House of the Australian Parliament is also known as the People’s House?
questions.explanation: Other names for the House of Representatives are the Lower House or the People’ s House

questions.questionText: The role and responsibilities of the Administrator are similar to who?
questions.explanation: The role and responsibilities of the Administrator are similar to those of a state Governor

questions.questionText: What is the term used for a government formed by representatives elected by the public?
questions.explanation: A democracy is a system of government in which citizens freely choose representatives to govern the country and make laws on their behalf.

questions.questionText: What is the name given to the process of considering a proposed new law for the purpose of accepting or rejecting it?
questions.explanation: To consider a proposal for a new law and decide whether to accept or reject it.

questions.questionText: What governing system does Australia follow?
questions.explanation: Australia’s system of government is a parliamentary democracy. This means that all Australians are involved in how the country is governed.

questions.questionText: What does the five-pointed white star of the flag of Torres Strait Islands symbolise?
options: A symbol for all Torres Strait Islanders
The island groups in the Torres Strait
questions.explanation: The points of the white star represent the island groups in the Torres Strait.

questions.questionText: Australians who feature in the electoral roll are not allowed to be part of a jury?
questions.explanation: Jury service is a responsibility for Australian citizens aged 18 years or over. A jury is a group of ordinary Australian men and women who listen to the evidence in a court case and decide if a person is guilty or not guilty. Any Australian who is on the electoral roll may be called to serve on a jury..

questions.questionText: The name of the capital city of Queensland is?
questions.explanation: Brisbane is Queensland’s capital city..

questions.questionText: What is the maximum number of representatives elected to the Senate from every state in Australia?
questions.explanation: The states are equally represented in the Senate, regardless of their population size. There are 12 representatives elected from each state.

questions.questionText: What type of government rule is seen in Australia?
questions.explanation: Government by the people through elected representatives.

questions.questionText: Who holds the power to change existing laws and make new ones in Australia?
questions.explanation: The Australian Parliament makes and changes laws to benefit the nation. State and territory parliaments make their own laws in a similar way.

questions.questionText: Choose the correct number of Australian states from the choices below:
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth of Australia is a federation of states and territories. There are six states and two mainland territories.

questions.questionText: What is the term used to describe carrying drugs or buying them illegally for the purpose of selling?
questions.explanation: Carrying or buying drugs to sell illegally.

questions.questionText: Law enforcement falls under which type of governing power?
questions.explanation: Australian Government ministers and the Governor-General have executive power to administer the laws made by the Australian Parliament.

questions.questionText: The appointment of Northern Territory’s administrator is done by?
questions.explanation: In the Northern Territory, an Administrator is appointed by the Governor-General.

questions.questionText: What do you pledge at the citizenship ceremony?
options: Share Australia's capitalist beliefs, respect people rights and liberties, uphold and obey Australian laws
Share Australia's communist beliefs, respect people rights and liberties, uphold and obey Australian laws
I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people, whose democratic beliefs I share, whose rights and liberties I respect, and whose laws I will uphold and obey.
questions.explanation: From this time forward, under God,* I pledge my loyalty to Australia and its people, whose democratic beliefs I share, whose rights and liberties I respect, and whose laws I will uphold and obey. * A person may choose whether or not to use the words ‘under God’.

questions.questionText: Name the nationality of the people who first established their colony in Australia?
questions.explanation: New South Wales was the first colony established by the British.

questions.questionText: Which city is the capital of Northern Territory?
questions.explanation: Darwin is the capital city of Northern Territory (NT).

questions.questionText: Name the colours present in the uniform worn by the national or the Australian sports teams?
questions.explanation: The uniforms of our national sports teams are usually green and gold.

questions.questionText: What does freedom of speech signify?
options: It allows people to write what they think
It allows people to say and discuss their ideas with others
questions.explanation: Freedom of speech allows people to say and write what they think and to discuss their ideas with others. However, we cannot harm others.

questions.questionText: What is the name of the first governor of New South Wales?
questions.explanation: The first governor of the colony of New South Wales was Captain Arthur Phillip. He brought the first fleet of 11 ships safely from Britain to the other side of the world.

questions.questionText: Which of the following statements regarding migration during early 20th century is false?
options: British migrants were actively encouraged to settle in Australia
The population increased to more than double
questions.explanation: Throughout the first half of the 20th century, migration levels rose and fell. There were programs to actively encourage British migrants to settle here, and many did.

questions.questionText: In which year did the British colonies unite and come under one umbrella called Commonwealth of Australia?
questions.explanation: In 1901, the colonies were united into a federation of states called the Commonwealth of Australia. At that time, Australia’s population was counted at about four million people. This number did not include the Indigenous people.

questions.questionText: n which state in Australia are most of the large mining projects located??
questions.explanation: Western Australia is the largest state. The east of the state is mostly desert, while the south-west is a rich agricultural and wine-growing area. The state is home to many large mining projects. About three-quarters of the state’s population lives in Perth, the capital city.

questions.questionText: When is remembrance day in Australia?
questions.explanation: As well as Anzac Day ceremonies, Remembrance Day is also a day on which Australians remember those who have served and died in war. At 11am on 11 November (the 11th month) each year, Australians pause to remember the sacrifice of the men and women who died or suffered in wars and conflicts, as well as all those who have served. We wear a red poppy on this day.

questions.questionText: n which city, High Court of Australia and Australian Parliament located?
questions.explanation: Canberra is home to important national institutions, such as Parliament House and the High Court of Australia.

questions.questionText: What is the current approximate population of Australia?
questions.explanation: Today, Australia has a population of about 25 million people. Over one quarter of these people were born overseas. Australia is greatly enriched by the contribution these people make to our nation. While we celebrate the diversity of Australia’s people, we also aim to build a cohesive and unified nation.

questions.questionText: In which year gold was discovered in the Colonies of New South Wales and Victoria?
questions.explanation: In 1851, gold was discovered in the colonies of New South Wales and Victoria. People from all around the world came to these colonies to try their luck at making a fortune. Chinese people arriving at this time were the first large group of migrants not from Europe. In 10 years, the population more than doubled.

questions.questionText: Commonwealth of Australia is a federation of states and territories?
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth of Australia is a federation of states and territories. There are six states and two mainland territories. Canberra is Australia’s capital city, and each state and mainland territory has its own capital.

questions.questionText: Is it true that Sydney is capital city of New South Wales?
questions.explanation: New South Wales was the first colony established by the British. Sydney is the capital city of New South Wales and is the nation’s largest city. Sydney’s Harbour Bridge and Opera House are national icons.

questions.questionText: Is Sydney's Harbour Bridge and Opera House are considered National icons of Australia?
Which of the following state is well known as wine regions and have rugged coastline?
questions.explanation: South Australia has a rugged coastline and many famous wine regions. Adelaide, the capital city, has many examples of fine colonial architecture.

questions.questionText: What happened in Australia on 1 January 1901?
options: The Australian Constitution was changed by a referendum
The Australian Constitution came into effect
The Australian and New Zealand Army Corps was formed
questions.explanation: The Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act 1900 is the legal document that sets out the basic rules for the government of Australia. The Australian Constitution was originally passed as part of a British Act of Parliament in 1900. On 1 January 1901, when the Constitution took effect, the Australian colonies became one independent nation, the Commonwealth of Australia

questions.questionText: On which of the following days Citizenship Ceremony programmes are held at many places across Australia?
questions.explanation: Australia Day is the day that we honour our history and all the people who have made this nation great. It is a day to rejoice in the present and commit to a happy and prosperous future together. For this reason, it is a day when many citizenship ceremonies are held across the country.

questions.questionText: Since how many years are the Aboriginal people living in mainland Australia and Tasmania?
questions.explanation: Historically, Aboriginal people are from mainland Australia and Tasmania. They have lived here for between 40 000 and 60 000 years.

questions.questionText: In which year did the British colonies unite and come under one umbrella called Commonwealth of Australia?
questions.explanation: In 1901, the colonies were united into a federation of states called the Commonwealth of Australia. At that time, Australia’s population was counted at about four million people. This number did not include the Indigenous people.

questions.questionText: Victoria is smallest of the mainland states?
In which year gold was discovered in the Colonies of New South Wales and Victoria?
questions.explanation: In 1851, gold was discovered in the colonies of New South Wales and Victoria. People from all around the world came to these colonies to try their luck at making a fortune. Chinese people arriving at this time were the first large group of migrants not from Europe. In 10 years, the population more than doubled.

questions.questionText: On which of these days Anzac Day is celebrated in Australia?
questions.explanation: Anzac Day is observed on 25 April each year. Anzac Day is named after the Australian and New Zealand Army Corps, which landed at Gallipoli in Turkey during World War I on 25 April 1915.

questions.questionText: In which city, High Court of Australia and Australian Parliament located?
questions.explanation: Canberra is home to important national institutions, such as Parliament House and the High Court of Australia.

questions.questionText: After which World war migration of non British people to Australia increased heavily?
questions.explanation: A wave of non-British migration came after World War II, when millions of people in Europe had to leave their homelands. Large numbers came to Australia to build a new life.

questions.questionText: How many languages are spoken in Australia because of multi racial, multi colour and diverse society?
questions.explanation: Australia’s national language is English. It is part of our national identity. Everyone in Australia is encouraged to learn and use English to help them participate in Australian society. Communicating in English is also important for making the most of living and working in Australia. Other languages are also valued. In Australia’s diverse society, over 200 languages are spoken.

questions.questionText: Should people in Australia make an effort to learn English?
options: People in Australia should speak whichever language is most commonly spoken in their local neighbourhood
Yes, only if you are looking for job in Australia
No, you can survive without learning English in Australia
Yes, English is the national language of Australia and it helps to get an education, a job, and to integrate into the community

questions.questionText: Can you pass racially abusive comments in public place in Australia?
options: Yes, as long as nobody objects to it
Yes, as long as they are passed at minority people
No, it is against Australian values and laws
Yes, as long as it doesn't involve physical violence

questions.questionText: Is It allowed to marry more than one person at the same time in Australia?
options: Yes, as long as it is registered in the court
Yes, as long as your existing partner approves it
Only when it is approved by your religion
No, it is against law and can result in severe legal penalties, including imprisonment.

questions.questionText: Which of the below is an example of undermining Australia’s interests and security?
options: Not protecting your assets by taking insurance
Criticising national policies on social media
Sharing secret government documents on social media

questions.questionText: Is it okay to apply for divorce from your partner, even when they want continue the marriage?
options: No, the marriage must be protected irrespective of your wishes
Yes, only when it is permitted by your parents
No, it is a sin and is punishable by society
Yes, either a husband or a wife may apply for a divorce to the courts, even if the other spouse wishes to continue the marriage.

questions.questionText: In Australia, can you create or promote racially offensive material to others?
options: Yes, if it is done via internet
Yes, as long as it is done in a small group
Yes, as long as you have mass following
No, it is against Australian values and laws

questions.questionText: Which of the following statements is true?
options: Anybody can protest against the government or an organisation
Anybody can protest against a government action or an organisation as long as it is lawful
Anybody can protest against the government or an organisation only when Police are present
Protests against government are illegal and are punishable under law

questions.questionText: Is it okay to write a post on Facebook to incite violence against a person or a group of people?
options: yes, as long as you delete the post later
yes, as long as nobody is injured
only when you have less than 1000 followers
no, it is against Australian values and law

questions.questionText: In Australia, can you stop a woman from getting ahead of men even when she has better qualifications and skills?
options: Yes, it is a right for a man to get a job ahead of a woman in Australia
No, in Australia, it is a right for a woman to get a job ahead of a man, if she has better qualifications and skills
Yes, men are always better at job than women
Yes, a woman can not get better position than a man in Australia irrespective of her qualifications and skills

questions.questionText: Is it legal in Australia for an adult to have sexual relations with a 15 year old girl?
options: Yes, as it is their personal choice
It is allowed in some states and territories
No, it is against the law in all Australian states and territories
Yes, if the girl consent to it

questions.questionText: Australian laws are applicable to?
options: Australian citizens, permanent residents and temporary visa holders

questions.questionText: When religious laws differ from Australian law, which of the following statements is true?
options: Australian law is above the religion and must be followed in any case
You can follow religious laws if they are approved by the Pope
Religious laws are above the Australian law and must be followed in any case
Religious laws can be followed as long as they have majority following

questions.questionText: Which of the below statement is correct?
options: Politicians are above the law as they create the law
Australian people only need to follow the guidelines laid down in their religious texts
Wealthy people don't need to follow the law
All Australians are equal in relation to the law and no person or group is above the law.

questions.questionText: In Australia, media such as newspapers, television and radio channels is controlled by ___________?
Is it true that only native people gets preference to the jobs compared to the immigrants?
options: Yes, the natives have constitutional right of preference to the jobs
Yes, the natives have better knowledge than the immigrants
No, a person should get a job based on their skills and experience, not because of their gender, wealth or ethnicity.
Yes, the natives have the first right to the job

questions.questionText: In Australia, is it true that people can get more or less opportunities based on their religion?
options: Yes, if your religion is not approved by the government, you will not get any opportunities to pursue your goals and interests.
No, all people should be provided equal opportunity to pursue their goals and interests regardless of their ethnicity or religion, as long as they obey the law.
Yes, people in minority can get less opportunities to pursue their goals and interests.
Yes, if you belong to a religion followed by majority

questions.questionText: Is it compulsory for an individual to join one of the Australian political parties??
options: No, a person is free not to join any political party
Only an Australian citizen need to join a political party
A person has to join a political party to show his loyalty to Australia
No, as long as the person is exempted by the Department of Foreign Affairs

questions.questionText: In Australia, does a woman have to ask permission from her parents for marriage?
options: Yes because parents have better judgement in these cases
No, in Australia both men and women have the right to make their own independent choices about personal matters, such as marriage
Yes, she has to marry according to their wish
Yes, if it is cultural norm and should be followed without question

questions.questionText: It is important to learn to speak English because ____________________________?
options: you can brag about your English skills
it is better than any other language
it is very easy to learn
it helps to get an education, a job, and better integrate into the community.

questions.questionText: Is it okay if people join a religious cult?
options: No, as cults are unlawful entity in Australia
Yes, if they are approved by the Pope
Yes, if they have are associated with a political party
Yes, as long as it is within the law.
